Module com.jlbabilino.json
Package com.jlbabilino.json

Class JSONSerializer

java.lang.Object
com.jlbabilino.json.JSONSerializer
public final class JSONSerializer extends Object

This class takes Java object inputs and converts them to JSON. This is useful for applications that need to save an object to a JSON file. JSON deserialization can be used to convert this JSON data back to Java objects.

A Java object may be serialized in several ways:

  1. Null serialization: If the object is null, it will be serialized as JSONNull.NULL
  2. Custom serialization: You can annotate your class with JSONSerializable to mark it for custom serilaization. This method allows you to control what fields and methods are serialized and what type of JSONEntry the object is serilaized to.
  3. JSON serialization: If the object is an instance of one of the JSONEntry subclasses, then the serialized object will the object put in. If the object is an instance of JSON, then it may be serialized as a JSONEntry or a JSON depending on which serialization method is used.
  4. Collection serialization: Java Collections will be serialized as JSON arrays by iterating over the entire collection then serializing each item and placing it in the JSON array.
  5. Map serilaization: Java Maps will be serialized as JSON objects. Each entry in the JSON object is collected by iterating over the map, then on each item, invoking toString() on the key to be used as the key in the JSON object, and serializing the value to be used for the value in the JSON object.
  6. Array serialization: Arrays will be serialized to JSON arrays, with each value collected through iteration on the array, then on each item, serializing the item to be placed in the JSON array. Ordering will always be preserved.
  7. Primative/Wrapper serialization: Java primatives may be serialized to different JSON entry types depending on the type:
    • Java Boolean objects (or primatives) are converted to JSONBoolean types.
    • Java Number objects (or primatives) are converted to JSONNumber types.
    • Java Character objects (or primatives) are converted to JSONString types with strings of length 1 containing the character.
  8. String serialization: Java strings will be serialized to JSONString strings, completely preserving data.

If the serilializer is unable to use any of the above methods, it will first attempt to automatically serialize the object. This is a good method for simple Java classes. Automatic serialization always serializes to JSON objects. It looks for public methods that have a name with prefix of "get", return anything but void, and have zero parameters. It will then get the substring after "get" to use for the key in the JSON object entry, then it will invoke the method and serialize the result for the value.

Custom serialization is the core of the second main part of this library, JSON serialization. As previously mentioned, you must mark a class with JSONSerializable to indicate that the serializer should do custom serialization. The annotation has one property, rootType, which indicates the JSON entry type you want the object to be serialized to. This property defaults to JSONEntry.JSONType.OBJECT.

For all JSON entry types, a single SerializedJSONEntry annotation can be used to indicate that a public field or method should be serialized and used as the serialization of the object. These public fields or methods must be accessible, and the methods must have zero parameters and not return void.class. This annotation is particularly helpful with objects and arrays where the size, indicies, and keys are specific to the Java object. Basically, it allows you to make variable length JSON arrays and dynamic JSON objects.

For classes that serialize to JSON objects, multiple fields and methods (of the same requirements) can be annotated with SerializedJSONObjectValue to indicate that they should be serialized and placed in the new JSON object as a key-value pair. SerializedJSONObjectValue has one property, key, which is the String that should be used as the key in the key-value pair. The value of the field or result of the method will be serialized and used as the value.

Similarly, for classes that serialize to JSON arrays, multiple fields and methods (of the same requirements) can be annotated with SerializedJSONArrayItem to indicate that they should be serialized and placed in the new JSON array as an array item. SerializedJSONArrayItem has one property, index, which is the int value that should be used as the index for the array item. The value of the field or result of the method will be serialized and placed in the new array at the index specified. The size of the new JSON array is equal to the largest index specified plus one, and any spaces not filled in the middle will be filled with JSON nulls.

Due to the recursive nature of JSON, serialization is also recursive. The methods that serialize Java objects are used recursively to serialize the fields of the object.
